name: Roman Theatre of Augusta Emerita
description: Built 16-15 BC by Marcus Vipsanius Agrippa, seats 6,000 spectators. Part of UNESCO World Heritage ensemble with adjacent amphitheatre. Exceptional preservation with original scaenae frons.

name: Roman Amphitheatre of Augusta Emerita
description: Dedicated in 8 BC for gladiatorial contests, seats 15,000. Located adjacent to the Roman theatre near the city wall. Underground areas visible.

name: Roman Bridge of Augusta Emerita
description: Spans 792m over Guadiana River, one of the largest surviving Roman bridges. Connects to Decumanus Maximus, still in use today.

name: Temple of Diana, Mérida
description: Late 1st century BC temple dedicated to Imperial cult. Municipal building of the city forum with preserved columns and architraves.

name: Los Milagros Aqueduct
description: Miraculous Aqueduct bringing water from Proserpina Dam 5km away. Spectacular arched structure with preserved pillars up to 25m high.

name: Roman Amphitheatre of Tarraco
description: Located near the seashore, measures 46m long. Well-preserved structure with associated basilica and Romanesque church remains. UNESCO World Heritage Site.

name: Aqueduct de les Ferreres (Pont del Diable)
description: Devil's Bridge crosses valley 4km from Tarragona. Two-tiered Roman aqueduct 21m long, exceptional engineering preserved over 2000 years.

name: Provincial Forum of Tarraco
description: Administrative center built at the top of the city during Flavian period (70-180 AD). Capital of Hispania Citerior province.

name: Segóbriga Archaeological Park
description: Caput Celtiberiae with theatre, amphitheatre (75m, capacity 5,500), Roman baths, forum, and city walls. Prospered from lapis specularis mining.

name: Itálica Archaeological Site
description: First Roman settlement in Spain (206 BC), birthplace of Trajan and Hadrian. Third largest amphitheatre in Empire (25,000 seats), Traianeum temple, exceptional mosaics.

name: Empúries Archaeological Site
description: Entry point of Roman invasion (218 BC). Preserves Greek Emporion and Roman Emporiae with walls, forum, houses and mosaics.

name: Baelo Claudia
description: Coastal Roman city with basilica, theatre, temples, and fish-salting factory. Shows African building influences, exceptional preservation.

name: Las Médulas
description: Largest Roman gold mine in the Empire. Spectacular red landscape created by hydraulic mining, preserved aqueducts, mining tunnels. UNESCO World Heritage Site.

name: Numantia
description: Famous Celtiberian city that resisted Roman siege until 133 BC. Symbol of indigenous resistance with preserved walls and foundations.

name: Roman Theatre of Caesaraugusta
description: 1st century theatre in Augustus' foundation. Preserved underground museum showing original structure with seating for 6,000.

name: Roman Walls of Lugo
description: Best-preserved Roman wall in the world, 2.2km perimeter, completely walkable. UNESCO World Heritage Site from 3rd century AD.

name: Basilica of San Juan Bautista
description: Built by King Recceswinth in 661 AD. Three-nave basilica with transept, horseshoe arches, rich sculptural decoration. Oldest dated Visigothic church.

name: Church of San Pedro de la Nave
description: Late 7th century church from King Égica's reign. Greek cross plan with decorated capitals depicting biblical scenes, relocated stone by stone.

name: Hermitage of Santa María de Lara
description: 8th century hermitage with preserved transept and sanctuary. Blue-grey stone blocks with reliefs of Christ and Virgin Mary, exceptional sculptural decoration.

name: Recópolis
description: Founded 578 AD by King Liuvigild. One of only two new cities built in Western Europe (5th-8th centuries). Preserved palace, basilica, walls with towers.

name: Roman Villa of Carranque
description: Late 4th century villa complex possibly of Maternus Cinigius. Exceptional mosaics depicting Oceanus, Hylas and Nymphs, 32 marble columns from emperor's quarries.

name: Roman Aqueduct of Segovia
description: Most famous Roman aqueduct in Spain, 728m long with 165 arches reaching 28m high. Built without mortar, still standing after 2000 years.

name: Tower of Hercules
description: Oldest surviving Roman lighthouse in the world, 2nd century AD. 55m high, still functioning, UNESCO World Heritage Site with original Roman core.

name: Crypt of San Antolín
description: 7th century Visigothic crypt beneath Palencia Cathedral. Preserved horseshoe arch, original capitals, unique underground sanctuary.
